text:
So I think neurodiversity is hostile to the ideas of the enlightenment.

It has 

And I think that, rather than politics, is the fundamental distinction between pro ND and anti ND.
And neurodiversity academia is characterised by qualitative methodology. There is little measurement.

But for me this is not enough to justify polarising ND in such political terms.

I myself am of the left. I buy into economics that bolster labour power. I believe in supra-national systems of governance. I oppose hereditary privilege.

And I oppose neurodiversity.

On Autism, neurodiversity and politics:

It is commonly acknowledged that neurodiversity is political. I agree.

It is also said that neurodiversity is broadly left wing, and that opposition to neurodiversity is broadly right wing.

I don’t agree. Here’s why.
@MattHancock Can you include autism, dyspraxia, dyscalculia, ADHD and ADDvin that bill please. Not fair to screen and support just one specific aspect of neurodiversity.

@DrJessTaylor @Emily_Mckenzie Read it again, and pause for a minute. You have to have had traits your whole life, not be diagnosed as a child. It's almost like ADHD women have been ignored. But you know that and you're grifting. Not everything is trauma and invalidating neurodiversity won't get you anywhere

@commaficionado I don’t find it offensive in any way, but I do think there is a danger of losing some of the utility of the term.
For me, neurodiversity refers to a brain that is not malfunctioning in any way, but operates in a way different to the accepted norm.

I’ve always loosely likened neurodiversity to evolution. 

Given our genetic intermixing, life circumstances, and the highly variable environments we’re been raised in, neurodiversity is inevitable. Nature and nurture and neurodiversity.

text:
@mrsfr0g @Kellyanne1977 @commaficionado I don't think the argument that ND people are more likely to have PTSD is necessarily a good one. Not all common commorbidities of neurodiversities are neurodiversities. 
I'm not saying PTSD isn't a neurodiversity, just that it isn't a particularly good argument that it is.

"Neurodiversity", as an umbrella term, makes a certain amount of sense — covering over autism, ADHD and the like. It has its value.

But it carries with it an implication  that a "neurodivergency" is not a disorder or disability, but simply "another variation" of human neurology.

text:
My anxiety is mental illness. 
My ADHD is neurodiversity. 

They inform each other, but they are different kinds of things. 

Calling everything neurodivergent suggests you can "treat" neurotype in the same way you can mental illness, which is dangerous AF.

A person is neurodivergent.

text: @commaficionado "Neurodivergent" & "neurodiversity" are different things. "Neurodivergent" was coined by Kassiane Asasumasu, & has always included mental illness. ND means any mind that diverges from what *systems of oppression are primed to accommodate*. "Neurodiversity" includes neurotypical.

text:
3) Neurodiversity as Politically Charged

Despite neurodiversity being valuable, brain types are politically charged in a similar way to having a specific skin colour. Some neurotypes dominate society (neurotypical) while others are oppressed (neurodivergent).
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |

text:
2) The Neurodiversity Principle

Instead, it is held that everyone's brains are different. This is similar to the biodiversity experienced in nature. Nature is full of variation which is valuable. Brains can also have valuable variation. This is Neurodiversity.
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |

text:
1) The Rejection of the Medical Model

The medical model holds that there is a specific type of brain that is 'healthy/normal'. If a brain is not normal then it is 'abnormal' and needs to be fixed to a state of normality. 

The Neurodiversity paradigm rejects this.
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |

text:
The Neurodiversity paradigm consists of three main assumptions. 

1)The Rejection of the Medical Model
2) The Neurodiversity Principle
3) Neurodiversity as Politically Charged. 

Let's examine each of these individually.
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |

text: Let's start with what a paradigm is. A paradigm is a set of assumptions which influence how a person views the world. The neurodiversity paradigm is thus a series of assumptions of how we view brains.
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |

text: The term Neurodiversity was coined in 1998 by Judy Singer (in her thesis 'Neurodiversity: the Birth of an Idea') and journalist Harvey Blume. The best explanation is Nick Walker's (She/Her). You can see it here:  https://t.co/a5jZx6SIBD
user_description: MA Philosophy of Mind and Cognitive Science | Writer, Researcher | Migraine and Neurodiversity Advocate | Editor of @P_A_Absurdum |
